overview: Why you might get a tax credits penalty and how you can pay or appeal one
title: Tax credits penalties

table.body:
The Tax Credit Office may charge a penalty if you:

- gave them wrong information - on purpose or by mistake
- didn't tell them about changes in your circumstances when you should have done
- didn't give them information or evidence they asked for

##Giving wrong information
If you have been paid too much tax credits because you gave wrong information, you can be charged up to £3,000. 

The Tax Credit Office may charge a penalty if you gave wrong information:

- on purpose - 'fraudulently' giving wrong information
- because you didn't take enough care - 'negligently' giving wrong information

You won't get a penalty if you made a mistake but took reasonable care when making a claim.

^If you realise you have given wrong information, let the [Tax Credit Office](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the Tax Credit Office") know straightaway.^

##You didn't report changes
The tax credits you get depend on your circumstances and income. 

You need to [report any changes](/report-changes-that-affect-your-tax-credits "Report changes that affect your tax credits") that affect your tax credits to make sure you are being paid the right amount. 

You need to [report some changes within a month](/report-changes-that-affect-your-tax-credits "Report changes that affect your tax credits"). For example if you stop work or your child leaves full time education. 

^If you don't report relevant changes, you could get a penalty of up to £300.^

##Not giving information or evidence
If the Tax Credit Office asks you for information or evidence you must send it to them. They might need the information to help them with a [tax credits check](/tax-credits-checks "Tax credit checks"). If you don't, you can get a penalty of up to £300 and an extra penalty of £60 a day until you provide the information. 

Let them know if you've got a good reason for not giving them the information. For example your documents may have been destroyed or you've been ill.

##Joint claims
If you've made a joint claim, you're both responsible for the information you give. The Tax Credit Office can charge you a penalty as a couple if:

- either of you could have told them about a change in circumstance
- you were both responsible for giving wrong information

If you give wrong information about yourself and your partner couldn't have known the information was wrong, you will get the penalty.

##How much will the penalty be?
You can talk to the [Tax Credit Office](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the Tax Credit Office") about lowering the maximum penalty.

They will take into account:

- how helpful you've been
- if you've freely given them information to calculate your tax credits
- the amount of tax credits you over-claimed
- if you've been charged a penalty before
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Depending on your situation you can pay the penalty in one go or in instalments.

s1. The Tax Credit Office will ask you to sign a letter with details of the payment
s2. You will get a final letter to accept the arrangement which then becomes a legal contract

If you refuse to pay, legal action can be taken to get the money you owe.

You may be charged **interest** if you either:

- 'negligently' gave wrong information (you did not take enough care)
- did not pay a penalty on time
table.title: How to pay

table.body:
Contact the [Tax Credit Office](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the Tax Credit Office") if you disagree with your penalty. If they can't agree with you, they'll send you a penalty notice.

You can then [appeal or ask a representative to appeal for you](/appeal-tax-credits-decision "Appeal a tax credits decision").
